newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Mandela, forced to choose, dumps Taiwan for Beijing.
newsitem.headline: Mandela, forced to choose, dumps Taiwan for Beijing.

text.p: South Africa on Wednesday abandonned a vain attempt to have diplomatic relations with two Chinas and announced it would ditch ties with Taiwan in favour of the more powerful Beijing.
The move grasped a diplomatic nettle that President Nelson Mandela's government -- to the detriment of a coherent foreign policy, according to some critics -- had long sought to avoid.

"We have now granted diplomatic recognition to the Peoples Republic of China. We will cancel our diplomatic relations with Taiwan with effect from December 1997," Mandela told a news conference at his home in Johannesburg.
Taiwan lost the biggest of its 30 diplomatic allies.
Mandela expressed his regret, praising Taiwan for its economic contribution to South Africa and its support for the country's transition to democracy over the past two years.
He said South Africa wanted continuing "constructive relations with Taiwan", but made clear that by the end of 1997 it would have ties with the communist People's Republic only.

Mandela said he met representatives of both Chinas on Tuesday and expressed the hope that "within the next twelve months it would be possible to achieve a smooth transition" allowing South Africa to remain friends with Taiwan.

Asked what had happened to his goal of ties with both Chinas, Mandela said: "Beijing made it clear they would not tolerate that. And it is impossible to move forward on the basis of dual recognition."

Enumerating reasons for the shift, he said China had the world's biggest population, an economy growing at 10 percent per year, a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council, and was recognised by almost every country in the world.
The new South Africa's active participation in the Organisation of African Unity and the Non-Aligned Movement, whose members recognise Beijing, also influenced the decision.
"A permanent continuation of diplomatic recognition of...Taiwan is inconsistent with South Africa's role in international affairs," he said. "We regret this very much."
The China decision was only one of several prickly issues on South Africa's diplomatic plate.

The government has been criticized for what some western critics see as over-friendly ties to Cuba, Libya and Iran. But Mandela has vowed not to ditch allies who aided his African National Congress when it was an outlawed black liberation movement.

Mandela said Pretoria's ties with Taiwan were inherited from South Africa's former whites-only government, but Taiwan had proved a valuable business partner to the new South Africa which took shape after his election to the presidency in April 1994.
Taiwan's embassy would go but "all other relations besides diplomatic relations will be maintained," he said.
Mandela, who said three months ago it would be "immoral" to dump Taiwan, expressed his readiness to meet Taiwan's president Lee Teng-hui to discuss the issue, declaring "I've got an open door."
But he left no doubt the decision was irrevocable.
In a bid to preserve its position in South Africa, Taiwan forecast recently that bilateral trade, totalling $1.9 billion in 1995, would grow by 10 percent a year.
Taipei also dangled the prospect of a $3.5 billion dollar petrochemical complex before South Africa's investment hungry eyes. But political imperatives proved stronger.
